title: How to Make a Laptop Stand from PVC Pipe
category_hierarchy: Digital Technology Art and Craft Projects

Two 7.5 inches (19cm) long{"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/3c/LTS-7pt5-inch.jpg/460px-LTS-7pt5-inch.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/3c/LTS-7pt5-inch.jpg/760px-LTS-7pt5-inch.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

steps.headline: Smooth the cut edges either by sanding or with a utility blade.
steps.description: You don't want any burrs of plastic sticking out to complicate assembly.

steps.headline: Set up a painting area outdoors.
steps.description: Use a sheet of cardboard or paper to protect surrounding surfaces if needed. Paint each piece and allow to dry thoroughly. If using more than one color of paint, paint the sections separately before assembling.

steps.headline: Assemble the sections as shown.
Complete the assembly, gluing each joint.
steps.description: Press each joint together firmly and adjust the angles before the glue sets.

steps.headline: Touch up any paint mishaps and you are ready to use your new laptop stand!

tyn: 3 to 4 ft (90cm to 1.2 meters) of PVC pipe and 6 90-degree elbows of the same diameter
Spray paint of your choice, suitable for PVC pipe
Marker (to mark the lengths of pipe for cutting)
text:
Preparing the PVC Pipe Measure and cut the following lengths of PVC pipe:One section 10.5 inches (26.6cm) long{"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b7/LTS---10-inch.jpg/460px-LTS---10-inch.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b7/LTS---10-inch.jpg/760px-LTS---10-inch.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Two 7.5 inches (19cm) long{"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/3c/LTS-7pt5-inch.jpg/460px-LTS-7pt5-inch.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/3c/LTS-7pt5-inch.jpg/760px-LTS-7pt5-inch.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Two 3.5 inches (8.8cm) long {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/ed/LTS-3pt5x2-inch.jpg/460px-LTS-3pt5x2-inch.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/ed/LTS-3pt5x2-inch.jpg/760px-LTS-3pt5x2-inch.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Smooth the cut edges either by sanding or with a utility blade. You don't want any burrs of plastic sticking out to complicate assembly. Set up a painting area outdoors. Use a sheet of cardboard or paper to protect surrounding surfaces if needed. Paint each piece and allow to dry thoroughly. If using more than one color of paint, paint the sections separately before assembling. Assembling the Laptop Stand Assemble the sections as shown. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/00/LTS---Assembly-1.jpg/459px-LTS---Assembly-1.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/00/LTS---Assembly-1.jpg/760px-LTS---Assembly-1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":332,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":549.1208791208791,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/8d/LTS---Assembly-2.jpg/460px-LTS---Assembly-2.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/8d/LTS---Assembly-2.jpg/760px-LTS---Assembly-2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":275,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":455.16483516483515,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d9/LTS---Assembled.jpg/460px-LTS---Assembled.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d9/LTS---Assembled.jpg/760px-LTS---Assembled.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":348,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":575.2197802197802,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Complete the assembly, gluing each joint. Press each joint together firmly and adjust the angles before the glue sets. Touch up any paint mishaps and you are ready to use your new laptop stand!
sentences:
Preparing the PVC Pipe Measure and cut the following lengths of PVC pipe:One section 10.5 inches (26.6cm) long{"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b7/LTS---10-inch.jpg/460px-LTS---10-inch.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b7/LTS---10-inch.jpg/760px-LTS---10-inch.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Two 7.5 inches (19cm) long{"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/3c/LTS-7pt5-inch.jpg/460px-LTS-7pt5-inch.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/3c/LTS-7pt5-inch.jpg/760px-LTS-7pt5-inch.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Two 3.5 inches (8.8cm) long {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/ed/LTS-3pt5x2-inch.jpg/460px-LTS-3pt5x2-inch.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/ed/LTS-3pt5x2-inch.jpg/760px-LTS-3pt5x2-inch.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Smooth the cut edges either by sanding or with a utility blade.
You don't want any burrs of plastic sticking out to complicate assembly.
Set up a painting area outdoors.
Use a sheet of cardboard or paper to protect surrounding surfaces if needed.
Paint each piece and allow to dry thoroughly.
If using more than one color of paint, paint the sections separately before assembling.
Assembling the Laptop Stand Assemble the sections as shown.

{"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/00/LTS---Assembly-1.jpg/459px-LTS---Assembly-1.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/00/LTS---Assembly-1.jpg/760px-LTS---Assembly-1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":332,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":549.1208791208791,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/8d/LTS---Assembly-2.jpg/460px-LTS---Assembly-2.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/8d/LTS---Assembly-2.jpg/760px-LTS---Assembly-2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":275,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":455.16483516483515,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d9/LTS---Assembled.jpg/460px-LTS---Assembled.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d9/LTS---Assembled.jpg/760px-LTS---Assembled.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":348,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":575.2197802197802,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Complete the assembly, gluing each joint.
Press each joint together firmly and adjust the angles before the glue sets.
Touch up any paint mishaps and you are ready to use your new laptop stand!
